posts.name: Brock
posts.cooked:
Our team is currently using Autodesk Fusion for CAD and machine our robot, but I’ve heard that many FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) teams use OnShape. I’m curious about the pros and cons of both tools and wonder what people like about each. As the offseason approaches, I’d really like to figure this out so we can train everyone properly without disrupting the program mid-offseason.

Thank you!

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: Yes (Onshape)

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: I was an intermediate or better Fusion user, and the school teaches some Fusion classes, though not to a very deep level. I examined the FRC landscape and determined that OnShape was superior for within-team multiplayer access, collaboration, and accessing CAD resources from other teams compared to FIRST. Both are parametric CAD systems, so proficiency in one facilitates learning the other through UI adaptation, sharing similar foundational approaches. We chose OnShape this year against some members' objections, but even those who were vocal later accepted OnShape as acceptable.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: Onshape, since it offers more FRC support for FIRST Robotics Competition.

posts.name: Monica
posts.cooked: One thing I really like about Onshape is the ability to use it on almost any device with an internet connection. Being able to quickly look up a dimension or assembly detail on your phone is pretty great.

posts.name: ehochstein
posts.cooked: I highly recommend using Onshape in conjunction with https://www.frcdesign.org.

As a former Fusion purist who switched to Onshape, I've found that Onshape is significantly better than Fusion for FRC purposes. While Fusion does include built-in CAM software, I believe Onshape offers a more effective solution for robotics competitions.

posts.name: JohnD 3322
posts.cooked:
Onshape is significantly superior to Fusion for FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) applications. While Fusion offers integrated CAM software, Onshape provides a more advantageous environment for our FRC-related tasks. Our company specializes in intricate CNC work, and I am seeking a compelling justification to transition away from Fusion's built-in CAM software.

Onshape excels in supporting FRC requirements, offering advanced tools tailored to our needs. Its capabilities likely surpass those of Fusion in handling complex FRC-related projects. Additionally, Onshape may provide better integration with other aspects of our CNC workflows, making it a more versatile choice for our operations.

The FRC community strongly supports Onshape, particularly its excellent learning resources such as frcdesign.org and the many featurescripts that greatly simplify tasks. My workflow has significantly improved due to the quality-of-life enhancements. Additionally, Onshape stands out because its browser-based nature facilitates more effective collaborative work compared to other software options. Notably, Onshape is more accessible than Fusion for Chromebook users, making it an ideal choice for students who are new to CAD.

posts.name: Will Weiszhaar
posts.cooked: Why not both? We use Onshape for creating the parts and Fusion for CAM processes. Once the setup is done initially, the workflow runs smoothly afterward.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Has anyone worked with the new Onshape CAM? Fusion CAM integration is one of the reasons we use it.

posts.name: Will Crawn
posts.cooked:
If you take the time, learning Onshape and organizing your documents before the season starts will significantly enhance your experience.

I'd recommend going through this CAD class. It provides a solid foundation in Onshape and highlights its applications in FRC projects.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design

posts.cooked: Haven't gotten our hands on it yet as access for EDU accounts comes out in the fall. Looks pretty promising but a bit unnecessary for us since we already have a Carbide Create Pro license.

posts.name: Jonathan Mi
posts.cooked: I see your team is registered for champs—I’d highly recommend you attend the FRCDesign workshop on Friday.

posts.name: Benjamen Johnson
posts.cooked: I'm not sure what you mean by the pipeline being tricky. We simply export a STEP file of the part from Onshape and import it into Fusion. The only issue is that whenever you modify a part, you need to reimport it into Fusion, but since we utilize fusion templates 90% of the time, it only takes us 10 seconds to set up the operations.

posts.name: Will Weiszhaar
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text:

"I admit I may have overestimated how hard it was to set up, but we encountered challenges when setting up templates."

posts.name: Jake
posts.cooked: My team uses Onshape, and while it’s been great except for the lack of offline support, we’ve managed to effectively share our CAD files across all devices. Since many of our devices at home are Chromebooks, being able to access the files wirelessly is especially convenient.

posts.name: Alex Weiss
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text, preserving the original meaning while adhering to the guidelines provided:

---

My team used Fusion 360, and it worked very well because we did all the CAM in-house. Fusion 360's CAM integrated seamlessly with our router and mill, neither of which had built-in CAM solutions. One advantage I noticed is that within Fusion, you can quickly edit parts without switching software. However, I haven't used Onshape CAM before, so I'm not sure how it compares. Another benefit of Fusion was its ability to perform offline editing, allowing us to work anywhere.

--- 

Let me know if this meets your needs!

posts.name: RedLeader342
posts.cooked: Having multiple CNC machines is more beneficial than having one without native CAM software, akin to how Carbide 3D functions. Our situation mirrors this choice; we face the same decision. Acquiring additional CNC machines might lead us to consider Fusion for CAM capabilities.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: We use Onshape for CAD and have Kiri:Moto installed as an app in Onshape for CAM and slicer for 3D printing. I don't think it's the most efficient tool for CAM, but we used it for all our CNC router work this year.

data.title: Should we use Fusion or Onshape Next Season?
data.fancy_title: Should we use Fusion or Onshape Next Season?
